title: John Yarmuth
deleted: Yarmuth filed candidacy papers on January 31, 2006, to represent {{ushr|Kentucky|3|}}. Having won the Democratic primary on May 16, defeating [[Andrew Horne]], Burrell Charles Farnsley and James W. Moore, he defeated incumbent [[Anne Northup]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]) in November of that year.

On August 7, 2006, ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' reported that ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' revealed a week before that the [[Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee]] had earmarked $51.5 million for television advertising in 32 congressional districts across the nation, but none for Yarmuth's challenge in the third congressional district.<ref>{{cite news |title=National Democratic campaign doesn't plan ads for Yarmuth |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/1755353091.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+7,+2006&author=&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=A.1&desc=National+Democratic+campaign+doesn't+plan+ads+for+Yarmuth |work=[[The Courier-Journal]] |date=August 7, 2006 |last=Stewart |first=Kay |access-date=September 1, 2006}}</ref>

On October 20, a ''Courier-Journal'' article stated that a [[WHAS-TV|WHAS11]]/[[SurveyUSA]] poll revealed the race had tightened dramatically, with Yarmuth leading Northup 48 to 47 percent. Another poll a month earlier had Northup leading by 6 points.<ref>{{cite news |title=Poll: Northup, Yarmuth race in dead heat |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/1755385121.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+20,+2006&author=&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=B.1&desc=Rep.+Northup's+campaign+cash+far+exceeds+that+of+foe+Yarmuth |last=Stewart |first=Kay |work=[[The Courier-Journal]] |date=October 20, 2006 |access-date=November 9, 2006}}</ref> A WHAS11/SurveyUSA poll released on November 2 showed Yarmuth leading Northup 52 to 44 percent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.whas11.com/news/politics/local/stories/WHAS11_TOP_SurveyUSAPollYarmuthNorthup.e9a3004.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070211160301/http://www.whas11.com/news/politics/local/stories/WHAS11_TOP_SurveyUSAPollYarmuthNorthup.e9a3004.html |archive-date=February 11, 2007 |title=Yarmuth ahead in new poll |date=November 2, 2006 |access-date=November 9, 2006 |work=whas11.com |first=Mark |last=Hebert}}</ref>

On October 26, Yarmuth told ''Courier-Journal'' reporter Kay Stewart that he would donate his congressional salary—which would be $168,500 in 2007—to local charity.<ref>{{cite news |title=Northup attacks Yarmuth's Wealth – Hypocrisy? |url=http://northupforcongress.blogspot.com/2006/10/northup-attacks-yarmuths-wealth.html |last=Stewart |first=Kay |work=[[The Courier-Journal]] |date=October 26, 2006 |access-date=January 2, 2008}}</ref>
Because polls close early in Kentucky, many analysts saw this race as a key indicator and it immediately became one of the most watched House races in the nation.
In the general election, Yarmuth garnered 122,139 votes (51%) to Northup's 116,157 votes (48%). Independent candidates garnered 2,896 votes (1%).

Yarmuth ran unopposed in the primary, and faced Anne Northup in a rematch of the 2006 general election.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.courier-journal.com/blogs/politics/2008/01/roberts-probably-out-northup-considers.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120729031002/http://www.courier-journal.com/blogs/politics/2008/01/roberts-probably-out-northup-considers.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 29, 2012 |title=Roberts probably out, Northup considers return |author=Gerth, Joe |work=[[The Courier-Journal]] |date=January 16, 2008}}</ref><ref name="ap2008">{{cite news|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/K/KY_NORTHUP_CAMPAIGN_KYOL- |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190120195203/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/K/KY_NORTHUP_CAMPAIGN_KYOL- |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 20, 2019 |title=Northup to run to regain former congressional seat, adviser says |author=Schreiner, Bruce |work=Associated Press |date=January 28, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Northup Files To Run For Old Congressional Seat |url=http://www.wlky.com/news/15159131/detail.html |work=WLKY.com |publisher=Internet Broadcasting Systems, Inc. |date=January 28, 2008 |access-date=April 20, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717065350/http://www.wlky.com/news/15159131/detail.html |archive-date=July 17, 2011 }}</ref>

Yarmuth won the 2008 election with 59% of the vote.<ref name="cnn">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/results/individual/#mapHKY/H/03|title=2008 General Election Results|publisher=CNN|date=November 5, 2008}}</ref>

Yarmuth was challenged by Republican Todd Lally and Independent Michael D. Hansen. Yarmuth was re-elected successfully with 53% of the vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fox41.com/story/13430643/kentucky-3rd-district|title=John Yarmuth wins Kentucky 3rd District|date=November 2, 2010|access-date=November 2, 2010|publisher=[[WDRB]]}}</ref>

Yarmuth was challenged by Republican Brooks Wicker and Independent candidate Robert L. Devore Jr.  Yarmuth received 206,385 votes (63.96%), Brooks Wicker received 111,452 votes (23.32%), and Robert L. Devore Jr. received 4,819 votes (1.49%).

In the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2014|2014 General Election]], Yarmuth was challenged by Republican Dr. Michael McFarlane and Independent Gregory Puccetti.  On October 6, 2014, [[Kentucky Educational Television]] hosted a [[Leaders' debate|debate]] which was broadcast live on Louisville's KET, and was moderated by KET host Bill Goodman.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/politics-blog/2014/10/06/yarmuth-and-macfarlane-debate-on-ket/16838337/|title= Yarmuth and MacFarlane debate on KET | publisher= the Courier Journal | date = October 6, 2014 | access-date = February 27, 2018}}</ref>  Yarmuth went on to win reelection with 63.5% of the votes cast.

Yarmuth was challenged by Republican Harold Bratcher and Independent Everett Corley.  Yarmuth won with 63% of the vote, receiving 212,388 votes.  Harold Bratcher received 37% of the vote, totaling 122,085 ballots cast in his name.  Everett Corley received no votes in the election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/elections/live_results/2016_general/house/ky.html |title=Live Results : 2016 KENTUCKY HOUSE ELECTION RESULTS |website=Realclearpolitics.com |access-date=November 12, 2016}}</ref>

On April 17, 2017, Yarmuth announced that he would run for a seventh term in the 2018 election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weku.fm/post/congressman-john-yarmuth-run-re-election-2018|title=Congressman John Yarmuth Running for reelection in 2018|website=weku.fm|access-date= April 18, 2017}}</ref> During the campaign, he lobbied for chairpersonship of the [[House Budget Committee]] and promised to hold hearings on [[Medicare for all]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Costello |first1=Darcy |title=courier journal |url=https://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2018/06/27/john-yarmuth-medicare-all-bill-hearing/738024002/ |access-date=14 November 2018}}</ref> Yarmuth won re-election with over 62% of the vote against [[Vickie Yates Glisson]], Kentucky's former Secretary of Health and Family Services.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Kentucky%27s_3rd_Congressional_District_election,_2018|title=Kentucky's 3rd Congressional District election, 2018|website=ballotpedia.org|access-date= November 13, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Vickie_Yates_Glisson|title=Vickie Yates Glisson|website=ballotpedia.org|access-date= November 6, 2019}}</ref> After the Democrats took the House, Yarmuth became Budget Committee chairman. In that position, he requested documents pertaining to the withholding of appropriated defense funds to Ukraine. As of November 2019, the administration of [[Donald Trump]] has only partly complied with the request.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2019/11/26/two-omb-officials-resigned-voicing-concerns-over-ukraine-aid-hold-official-testifies/ Two OMB officials resigned in part over concerns about Ukraine aid hold, official testifies], ''[[Washington Post]]'', Erica Werner and Felicia Sonmez, November 26, 2019. Retrieved November 27, 2019.</ref>
